@article{10.1145/226643.226644,
author = {Selman, Bart and Kautz, Henry},
title = {Knowledge compilation and theory approximation},
year = {1996},
issue_date = {March 1996},
publisher = {Association for Computing Machinery},
address = {New York, NY, USA},
volume = {43},
number = {2},
issn = {0004-5411},
url = {https://doi.org/10.1145/226643.226644},
doi = {10.1145/226643.226644},
abstract = {Computational efficiency is a central concern in the design of knowledge representation systems. In order to obtain efficient systems, it has been suggested that one should limit the form of the statements in the knowledge base or use an incomplete inference mechanism. The former approach is often too restrictive for practical applications, whereas the latter leads to uncertainty about exactly what can and cannot be inferred from the knowledge base. We present a third alternative, in which knowledge given in a general representation language is translated (compiled) into a tractable form—allowing for efficient subsequent query answering.We show how propositional logical theories can be compiled into Horn theories that approximate the original information. The approximations bound the original theory from below and above in terms of logical strength. The procedures are extended to other tractable languages (for example, binary clauses) and to the first-order case. Finally, we demonstrate the generality of our approach by compiling concept descriptions in a general frame-based language into a tractable form.},
journal = {J. ACM},
month = mar,
pages = {193–224},
numpages = {32},
keywords = {Horn clauses, efficient reasoning methods, knowledge compilation, knowledge-base optimization, query evaluation, theory approximation}
}

relationTypes.name: No Poly, Unknown Quasi
relationTypes.label: ⊄_p, ?≤_q
relationTypes.description: No polynomial transformation, quasi-polynomial unknown (A ⊄_p B and A ?≤_q B)

relationTypes.name: No Poly, Has Quasi
relationTypes.label: ⊄_p, ≤_q
relationTypes.description: No polynomial but quasi-polynomial exists (A ⊄_p B and A ≤_q B)

relationTypes.name: Unknown Poly, Has Quasi
relationTypes.label: ?≤_p, ≤_q
relationTypes.description: Polynomial unknown but quasi-polynomial exists (A ?≤_p B and A ≤_q B)

relationTypes.name: Both Unknown
relationTypes.label: ?≤_p, ?≤_q
relationTypes.description: Both polynomial and quasi-polynomial unknown (A ?≤_p B and A ?≤_q B)

relationTypes.name: Not Polynomial
relationTypes.label: ⊄_p
relationTypes.description: Not polynomial (generated by "Polytime vs not polytime" filter)

smoothness.label: Smoothness
smoothness.description: All disjuncts mention the same variables

read-once.label: Read-Once
read-once.description: Each variable appears at most once on any path

CO.label: Consistency
CO.description: Check if the formula is satisfiable

VA.label: Validity
VA.description: Check if the formula is a tautology

CE.label: Clausal Entailment
CE.description: Check if a clause is entailed

IM.label: Implicant
IM.description: Find an implicant of the formula

EQ.label: Equivalence
EQ.description: Check logical equivalence of two formulas

SE.label: Sentential Entailment
SE.description: Check if one formula entails another

CT.label: Model Counting
CT.description: Count the number of satisfying assignments

not-poly-conditional.label: Not Poly (Conditional)
not-poly-conditional.description: Not polynomial under complexity assumption (e.g., Unless P=NP)

matrix.description: BDD is a subset of DNNF
Derived via polynomial transitive closure
Holds transitively
Holds transitively

It is straightforward to convert a clause into an equivalent sentence in BDD. In order
to generate a BDD sentence corresponding to the conjunction of BDD sentences α and β, it is sufficient to replace the 1-sink of α with the root of β.
See the proof in Darwiche 2002 page 247.

separatingFunctions.name: $\Sigma_n = \bigwedge_{i=0}^{n-1} \left( x_{2i} \vee x_{2i+1} \right)$
separatingFunctions.description: This formula helps separate PI from IP, among other important separations.

matrix.description:
Unless the polynomial hierarchy collapses:

"If $\mathrm{DNNF} \le \mathrm{CNF}$, then for each sentence $\Sigma$ in $\mathrm{CNF}$ there exists a poly-size equivalent sentence $\Gamma$ in $\mathrm{DNNF}$. Therefore, we can test whether a clause is entailed by $\Sigma$ in polynomial time by testing whether the clause is entailed by $\Gamma$. This proves the existence of poly-size knowledge-compilation functions for clausal entailment, leading to the collapse of the polynomial hierarchy $\mathrm{PH}$.

The same is true for $\mathrm{d\text{-}DNNF}$ and $\mathrm{sd\text{-}DNNF}$ since all these languages support a polytime clausal‐entailment test."
See the proof in Darwiche 2002 page 247

separatingFunctions.name: $\Sigma_n = \bigwedge_{i=0}^{n-1} \left( x_{2i} \vee x_{2i+1} \right)$
separatingFunctions.description: This formula helps separate PI from IP, among other important separations.

matrix.description: CNF is a subset of NNF
See the proof in Darwiche 2002 p. 247

matrix.description: It is straightforward to convert a term into an equivalent sentence in BDD. In order to generate a BDD sentence corresponding to the disjunction of BDD sentences α and β, it is sufficient to replace the 0-sink of α with the root of β.
See the proof on page 247 of Darwiche 2002.

separatingFunctions.name: $\Sigma_n = \bigwedge_{i=0}^{n-1} \left( x_{2i} \vee x_{2i+1} \right)$
separatingFunctions.description: This formula helps separate PI from IP, among other important separations.

matrix.description: DNF is a subset of DNNF

"In (Wegener, 1987) (Theorem 6.2, p. 436), a family of $n^2$-variable Boolean functions $\Sigma$ is defined. Every interpretation $I$ over these $n^2$ variables represents an $n$-vertex digraph (as for every $1 \le i,j \le n$, we have $I(x_{i,j}) = 1$ iff $(i,j)$ is an arc of the digraph).
Then $\Sigma(I) = 1$ iff the digraph represented by $I$ contains a $k$-clique of a special kind
($k$ is a parameter of the family).

It is shown that for certain values of $k$ (depending on $n$), every FBDD representation of
$\Sigma$ has exponential size. Moreover, it is shown that $\Sigma$ has only a cubic number of
prime implicants. This implies that
$$
\mathrm{FBDD} \not\le \mathrm{IP},
\quad\text{hence}\quad
\mathrm{FBDD} \not\le \mathrm{DNF}.
$$

Because FBDD satisfies $\neg C$ (see Proposition 5.1), it cannot be the case that $\neg\Sigma$
has a polynomial-size FBDD. Since $\neg\Sigma$ has only a cubic number of prime implicates, we obtain
$$
\mathrm{FBDD} \not\le \mathrm{PI},
\quad\text{hence}\quad
\mathrm{FBDD} \not\le \mathrm{CNF}.
$$

The remaining results ... follow since
$$
\mathrm{FBDD} \le \mathrm{OBDD} \le \mathrm{OBDD}< .
$$"
See the proof in Darwiche 2002 page 247

matrix.description: Holds transitively
This holds due to transitivity.
Hidden weighed bit functions can be represented by quadratic size FBDD but require exponential size OBDD's. Since an FBDD is an NNF formula this holds.
The parity function has a linear size representation in OBBD$_<$ but has $2^n$ essential prime implicates, a lower bound on the size of CNF.
